column1: It was near six in the May morning when Dick began to ride down into the fen upon his homeward way. The sky was all blue; the jolly wind blew loud and steady; the windmill-sails were spinning; and the willows over all the fen rippling and whitening like a field of corn. He had been all night in the saddle
column2: but his heart was good and his body sound
column3: and he rode right merrily.The path went down and down into the marsh
column4: till he lost sight of all the neighbouring landmarks but Kettley windmill on the knoll behind him
column5: and the extreme top of Tunstall Forest far before. On either hand there were great fields of blowing reeds and willows
column6: pools of water shaking in the wind
column9: to tempt and to betray the traveller. The path lay almost straight through the morass. It was already very ancient; its foundation had been laid by Roman soldiery; in the lapse of ages much of it had sunk
column12: it lay submerged below the stagnant waters of the fen.
